page.title: 01ABOUT WANBOROUGH
page.content: Any account of Wanborough is bound up in history. An ancient British road (The Rigeway)runs across the southern tip.This was crossed by the Roman road of Ermin Way from Cirencester to Speen,so Wanborough was an important meeting place for nomadic people and for roman soldiers on the march. A sizeable Roman villa was at the northern end of the village (durocornovium) of the name of nidum, which gives us the modern Nythe.The site was excavated by a local antiquarian, Mr.Passmore, and his findings of coins, pots, etc.Are now in the museum at Devizes.In Anglo-saxon times the center of the village moved up to the spring -line and the Icknield way developed to link Wanborough with the neighbouring "tons".A battle was fought in the area of Wanborough plain beyond the Ridgewa
